abstract_summ: Using daily COVID-19 confirmed cases and deaths and stock market returns data from 64 countries over the period January 22, 2020 to April 17, 2020, we find that stock markets responded negatively to the growth in COVID-19 confirmed cases.Abstract In this paper, we examine the stock markets’ response to the COVID-19 pandemic.Overall, our results suggest that stock markets quickly respond to COVID-19 pandemic and this response varies over time depending on the stage of outbreak.Therefore, this article provides pieces of evidence for the COVID-19 fractal contagion effect on the stock markets.Using an event study method, our results indicate that the stock markets in major affected countries and areas fell quickly after the virus outbreak.

title_abstract_phrases: Further panel fixed effect regressions also support the adverse effect of COVID-19 confirmed cases on stock indices abnormal returns through an effective channel by adding up investors’ pessimistic sentiment on future returns and fears of uncertainties.The contagion effects of the COVID-19 pandemic: Evidence from Gold and CryptocurrenciesAbstract At the beginning of the 2020 global COVID-2019 pandemic, Chinese financial markets acted as the epicentre of both physical and financial contagion.The COVID-19 Outbreak and Affected Countries Stock Markets ResponseThis paper evaluates the short-term impact of the coronavirus outbreak on 21 leading stock market indices in major affected countries including Japan, Korea, Singapore, the USA, Germany, Italy, and the UK etc.Using daily COVID-19 confirmed cases and deaths and stock market returns data from 64 countries over the period January 22, 2020 to April 17, 2020, we find that stock markets responded negatively to the growth in COVID-19 confirmed cases.Stock Markets and the COVID-19 Fractal Contagion EffectsThis article investigates the fractal contagion effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on the stock markets.
